required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on May 29, 2018
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: A Safety and Effectiveness Study of Intraspinal Gabapentin (MDT2004) for the Treatment of Chronic Pain
clinical_study.official_title: A Randomized Double Blind, Placebo-controlled, Dose Response Study of Intraspinal Gabapentin (MDT2004) in Subjects With Chronic, Intractable Pain.

brief_summary.textblock: The purpose of this study is to determine the safety and minimum effective dose of intraspinal gabapentin when delivered through an implanted drug infusion system.

clinical_study.why_stopped: Study closed and subject follow-up completed following analysis of blinded study data.

primary_outcome.measure: Changes in a Pain Rating Scale After 3 Weeks of Blinded Treatment.
primary_outcome.description: Average pain score calculated over last 7 days of baseline minus average pain score calculated over last 7 days of follow-up using the Numeric Pain Rating Scale where 0=no pain, 10=worst possible pain.

primary_outcome.measure: Number of Participants With Treatment-emergent Adverse Events
primary_outcome.time_frame: Randomization to Post-randomization Day 29 (includes dose reduction)
primary_outcome.description: Evaluation of adverse event profiles between placebo and active treatment groups.

secondary_outcome.measure: Responder Analysis Between Active Treatment and Placebo Groups.
secondary_outcome.description: Responders were subjects that reported at least a 30% decrease in average daily pain scores between baseline and Day 22.

arm_group.description: Intraspinal Placebo delivered continuously for 29 days via an implantable infusion system
Intraspinal Gabapentin Low delivered continuously for 22 days via an implantable infusion system followed by 7 days infusion at half dose
Intraspinal Gabapentin Medium delivered continuously for 22 days via an implantable infusion system followed by 7 days infusion at half dose
Intraspinal Gabapentin High delivered continuously for 22 days via an implantable infusion system followed by 7 days infusion at half dose

intervention.description: Surgical implantation of a drug infusion system with intrathecal (spinal) delivery of active drug (1 of 3 possible dose levels) or placebo (saline) for 22 days followed by 7 days of infusion at half dose level. Subjects may then continue in open-label treatment with study drug. Dosage in open-label may be adjusted to meet subject needs.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Chronic pain below the neck present for a minimum of one year.
- Diagnosis of at least one of the following:
- back pain with or without leg pain,
- post-herpetic neuralgia,
- complex regional pain syndrome (CRPS) 1 or 2,
- diabetic neuropathy,
- or a general neuropathic condition; medically stable and able to undergo surgery for implantation of the drug infusion system.

facility.name: WK River Cities Clinical Research Center
Oregon Health & Science University, Neurosurgery Department
Lehigh Valley Hospital Center for Pain Management

participant_flow.recruitment_details: A total of 254 subjects were enrolled into the study between December 2006 and October 2009.
participant_flow.pre_assignment_details: During a 2-week screening period subjects were required to meet eligibility criteria including maintaining stable pain medications and demonstrating a numerical pain rating score of 6 or greater averaged over the last 7 days of screening. A total of 170 subjects met eligibility criteria, were implanted with an infusion system and were randomized.

outcome.title: Changes in a Pain Rating Scale After 3 Weeks of Blinded Treatment.
outcome.description: Average pain score calculated over last 7 days of baseline minus average pain score calculated over last 7 days of follow-up using the Numeric Pain Rating Scale where 0=no pain, 10=worst possible pain.
outcome.population: Primary efficacy analysis was performed on the 167 randomized subjects that completed at least 4 days of the electronic pain diary during the last 7 days prior to the Day 22 or Early Termination Visit as per protocol. No imputation methods were used.

measure.title: Changes in a Pain Rating Scale After 3 Weeks of Blinded Treatment.
measure.description: Average pain score calculated over last 7 days of baseline minus average pain score calculated over last 7 days of follow-up using the Numeric Pain Rating Scale where 0=no pain, 10=worst possible pain.
measure.population: Primary efficacy analysis was performed on the 167 randomized subjects that completed at least 4 days of the electronic pain diary during the last 7 days prior to the Day 22 or Early Termination Visit as per protocol. No imputation methods were used.

analysis.groups_desc: Williams' test for Minimum Effective Dose was used to compare each active group to the placebo.
analysis.p_value_desc: The a priori threshold for statistical significance was 0.05, two-sided.
analysis.method: Williams test for minimum effective dose

analysis.groups_desc: Williams' test for Minimum Effective Dose was used to compare each active group to the placebo.
analysis.p_value_desc: The a priori threshold for statistical significance was 0.05, two-sided.
analysis.method: Williams test for minimum effective dose

analysis.groups_desc: Williams' test for Minimum Effective Dose was used to compare each active group to the placebo.
analysis.p_value_desc: The a priori threshold for statistical significance was 0.05, two-sided.
analysis.method: Williams test for minimum effective dose

outcome.title: Responder Analysis Between Active Treatment and Placebo Groups.
outcome.description: Responders were subjects that reported at least a 30% decrease in average daily pain scores between baseline and Day 22.
outcome.population: All 170 randomized subjects were included as per protocol. Subjects experiencing an intolerable adverse event, discontinuing due to an adverse event or lack of efficacy, or not providing data were considered non-responders.

measure.title: Responder Analysis Between Active Treatment and Placebo Groups.
measure.description: Responders were subjects that reported at least a 30% decrease in average daily pain scores between baseline and Day 22.
measure.population: All 170 randomized subjects were included as per protocol. Subjects experiencing an intolerable adverse event, discontinuing due to an adverse event or lack of efficacy, or not providing data were considered non-responders.

analysis.p_value_desc: The a priori threshold for statistical significance was 0.05, two-sided. Hochberg's adjustment for multiple comparisons was used.

reported_events.time_frame: Adverse events are reported through 29 days post-randomization, including 22 days of dosing at the randomized dose and 7 days of dose reduction.
reported_events.desc: All randomized subjects were included in adverse event summaries.

certain_agreements.pi_employee: Principal Investigators are NOT employed by the organization sponsoring the study.
certain_agreements.restrictive_agreement: The only disclosure restriction on the PI is that the sponsor can review results communications prior to public release and can embargo communications regarding trial results for a period that is less than or equal to 60 days. The sponsor cannot require changes to the communication and cannot extend the embargo.
